title: Synthesis of gold–tin alloy nanoparticles with tunable plasmonic properties

Step-by-step method details
Synthesis of citrate-capped Au nanoparticle seeds
Timing: 30 min
This preparation describes the synthesis of Au seed using the Turkevich method (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1], Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1] “Synthesis of Au Seeds”).2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]
Preparation of 10 mM HAuCl4 and 100 mM trisodium citrate precursor solutions:
Carefully weigh 39.4 mg of HAuCl4 trihydrate on an analytical balance into a 20 mL glass scintillation vial. Add 10 mL of ultrapure water to yield a 10 mM solution.
Carefully weigh 58.8 mg of trisodium citrate dihydrate on an analytical balance into a glass scintillation vial. Add 2 mL of ultrapure water to yield a 100 mM solution.
Synthesis setup and Au seed synthesis (Figure 1A[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]):
See Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for the exact volume of each reagent solution required.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2799_1.csv
Transfer the ultrapure water to a clean 250 mL round bottom flask.
Place a clean 25.4 mm PTFE stir bar into the flask and place on the 120 V 250 mL heating mantle resting on a stir plate.
Set the heating mantle and attached heat controller to 138°C and initiate stirring at 640 r.p.m.
Fasten a condenser to the neck of the round bottom flask, turn on water for circulation through the condenser, and ensure all components are securely attached to a ring stand with minimal motion of the reaction setup (Figure 1B[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
Once the water is boiling (100°C) and the reaction vessel is visibly at reflux, remove the condenser—leaving the round bottom flask on top of the heating mantle/hot plate.
Directly pipette the 10 mM HAuCl4 solution. Place the condenser back onto the reaction vessel.
Once the reaction system returns to reflux (after approximately 1–2 min), remove the condenser.

Rapidly pipette the 100 mM trisodium citrate solution in a single injection. Re-attach the condenser to the flask and heat/stir for 8 min.

Critical: Ensure the injection of the 100 mM citrate solution occurs as rapidly as possible; do not add slowly or in multiple injections.
After 8 min, carefully remove the reaction vessel from the heating/stirring apparatus. Allow to return to room temperature before proceeding with further reactions or optical characterization.

Synthesis of bimetallic Au–Sn nanoparticles
Timing: 1 h
This process details the preparation of precursor solutions and the chemical reduction and diffusion of Sn into the Au nanoparticle seeds (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2], Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2] “Reduction of Sn and diffusion into Au seeds”). Detailed below are the 10, 20, 30, and 40% molar equivalent additions of Sn.

Preparation of 10 wt.% polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), 5 mM SnCl4, and 260 mM NaBH4 solutions.
10 wt.% PVP solution preparation:
Carefully weigh 0.1 g of PVP into a 20 mL clean glass scintillation vial; add 1 mL of ultrapure water and swirl until fully dissolved.
Note: If necessary, sonicate the vial containing the PVP and ultrapure water to expedite the solid dissolving into solution.
5 mM SnCl4 solution preparation:
Carefully pipette 7.5 mL of ultrapure water into a clean glass vial.
In a fume hood and using a micropipette, carefully and rapidly add 4.34 μL of SnCl4 to the vial. Swirl until fully dissolved.
260 mM NaBH4 solution preparation:
Carefully weigh 20 mg of NaBH4 into a clean glass vial.
Critical: Do not add ultrapure water to the solid NaBH4 until immediately prior to the injection of the 260 mM NaBH4 in the reduction step. Once water is added, the solution should be used as quickly as possible and should not be stored for future use.
Add 2.03 mL of ultrapure water to the vial and swirl until dissolved.
Addition of Sn to Au seeds to form bimetallic nanoparticles (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
To a clean glass vial, pipette 6 mL of as-synthesized Au seeds, water, and add a 12.7 mm PTFE stir bar.
Add vials back to the stir plates (Figure 3A[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]) and begin stirring at 1,500 rpm. See Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2] for the exact volume of each precursor solution required.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2799_2.csv
While solutions are stirring, pipette the 10 wt.% PVP solution into the vial.
Add the 5 mM SnCl4 solution to the vial; one can inject this solution immediately after addition of PVP to the vials.
Remove the reaction vials from the stir plates and cap.

Place the entire capped vial into a hot water bath at 60°C for 10 min (Figure 3B[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]). The stir bar does not need to be removed from the reaction setup during this step.
After 10 min, uncover the vials and place back on to the stir plates and resume stirring.
To the vials, pipette the freshly prepared 260 mM NaBH4. Upon dispensing of the reduction agent, the solution should visually change to a translucent, homogeneous yellow-orange color with residual bubble formation on the top of the suspensions. Allow this solution to stir for 30 s.
Again, remove the entire reaction vial from the stir plates, cover, and place them into the hot water bath at 60°C for 20 min.
Note: Leave the reaction vials with slightly loosened caps during the 20-minute heating step (in the hot water bath) to allow for gas evolution from the reduction process.
Remove the vials from the 60°C hot water bath.
Remove the 12.7 mm PTFE stir bars from the sample solutions, with the assistance of another stir bar, upon removal from the hot water bath.
Allow colloidal suspensions to return to room temperature before characterizing.
Critical: A minimal color change occurs during the second heating, but importantly they should remain fully homogeneous colloidal suspensions with no visible flakes or precipitation.

Optical characterization of plasmonic bimetallic nanoparticles
Timing: 30 min
This process describes the process required to optically characterize the synthesized bimetallic nanocrystals to effectively understand localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR). Specifically, multichannel UV-visible spectroscopy will be used.
Perform background and blank correction using ultrapure water pipetted directly into the quartz cuvette.

Samples prepared in Step 4, can be pipetted directly into a clean 1 cm path-length quartz cuvette without dilution or concentration of the colloid to obtain the UV-visible spectrum.
Measure the UV-visible spectrum over a range of 200–700 nm and ensure data is appropriately saved on your device.
Structural characterization of bimetallic Au–Sn nanoparticles
Timing: 3 h
Characterization of crystalline features, size distribution, and nanoparticle morphology will be described through the use of XRD and TEM. This protocol describes the sample preparation, instrumentation settings, and steps required for the analysis using a powder X-ray diffractometer and transmission electron microscope.
Powder XRD sample preparation and characterization:
Pipette samples into 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes and place into centrifuge.
Centrifuge samples at 8,000 r.p.m. (5,510 r.c.f.) for 8 min.
After centrifugation carefully remove supernatant and leave the pellet.
Re-suspend the pellet into solution by adding 1.5 mL ultrapure water. Ensure sample is evenly distributed by inverting the microcentrifuge tubes.
Place the washed samples back into the centrifuge for a second centrifugation at 8,000 r.p.m. (5,510 r.c.f.) for 8 min.
Carefully remove the supernatant again, leaving only the concentrated sample in each microcentrifuge tube.
Pipette the concentrated sample onto a zero-background silicon background holder for the Rigaku Miniflex X-ray diffractometer.
Allow samples to visibly dry by placing in a desiccator uncovered.
Place samples onto the holders in the Rigaku Miniflex (utilizing Cu Kα X-ray source with 1.54 Å wavelength) and measure the diffraction pattern at a scan rate of 1° min-1 in the 2θ range 10–90°.
Ensure all data is saved for future analysis.
TEM sample preparation and characterization:
Pipette samples into 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes and place into centrifuge.
Centrifuge samples at 8,000 r.p.m. (5,510 r.c.f.) for 8 min.
After centrifugation, carefully remove the supernatant and leave the concentrated sample at the bottom.

Re-suspend the concentrated sample back to 1.5 mL by adding ultrapure water. Ensure sample is evenly distributed by inverting the microcentrifuge tubes.
Place the washed samples back into the centrifuge for another centrifugation at 8,000 r.p.m. (5,510 r.c.f.) for 8 min.
Carefully remove the supernatant again, leaving only the concentrated sample in each microcentrifuge tube.
Pipette 10 μL of the concentrated sample onto a Ted Pella Cu Carbon Type-B TEM grid.
Allow samples to dry completely in a desiccator uncovered for approximately 2 h.
Bimetallic nanoparticles were imaged using a 100 kV accelerating voltage and ImageJ software for size and polydispersity analysis.
Ensure all imaging and data is saved appropriately for future analysis.
